title.narrative: Strengthening peace through Rule of Law and employment, facilitated by education in Tigray

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: The DISH e-learning platform: Ethiopian partners join online platform
Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:

How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+

title.narrative: A.R.2. Number of relevant publications (level, gender, inclusion)

comment.narrative: 2 policy papers (output 3.3)
3 relevant publications are produced on gaps in the labour market (output 3.2); 2 peer reviewed articles, 1 policy paper (output 3.3)

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

comment.narrative: 4 new MoUs have been developed and signed between education institutions, private, public, and community organisations in relation to youth employment and education, and peace-building. (output 2.3)
3 new MoUs have been developed and signed between education institutions, private, public, and community organisations in relation to youth employment and education, and peace-building. (output 2.3)

comment.narrative: 90% of students enrolled will graduate
90% of students enrolled will graduate

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: At least 30 staff have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills through 3 exchanges and trainings to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes (24 teachers/researchers, 6 PhD/student staff, at least 30% female) (output 2.1); 50 Mekelle, Adwa and Aksum staff, PhDs and student staff have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes (20 teachers, 10 PhDs, 20 student staff (output 2.2)

At least 20 staff have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills through 3 exchanges and trainings to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes (16 teachers/researchers, 4 PhD/student staff, at least 30% female) (output 2.1); 50 Mekelle, Adwa and Aksum staff, PhDs and student staff have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes (20 teachers, 10 PhDs, 20 student staff (output 2.2)
